On the dimension effect of regularized linear discriminant analysis

Cheng Wanglabel=e1]chengwang@sjtu.edu.cn [ ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Binyan Jianglabel=e2]by.jiang@polyu.edu.hk [ School of Mathematical Sciences,
Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China.
Department of Applied Mathematics,
The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Kowloon, Hong Kong.
(2018)
Abstract

This paper studies the dimension effect of the linear discriminant analysis (LDA) and the regularized linear discriminant analysis (RLDA) classifiers for large dimensional data where the observation dimension pùëùp is of the same order as the sample size nùëõn. More specifically, built on properties of the Wishart distribution and recent results in random matrix theory, we derive explicit expressions for the asymptotic misclassification errors of LDA and RLDA respectively, from which we gain insights of how dimension affects the performance of classification and in what sense. Motivated by these results, we propose adjusted classifiers by correcting the bias brought by the unequal sample sizes. The bias-corrected LDA and RLDA classifiers are shown to have smaller misclassification rates than LDA and RLDA respectively. Several interesting examples are discussed in detail and the theoretical results on dimension effect are illustrated via extensive simulation studies.

1 Introduction

Discriminant analysis that aims to allocate objects into one of the predefined classes has been an important topic in statistical learning and data analysis. Modern data is frequently featured by complex structures such as high dimensionality. In the past decades, extensive research has been done to address new challenges of high dimensionality in discriminant analysis. In particular, due to its simplicity, optimality (Anderson, 2003), and promising performance in real data analysis (Hand, 2006), the linear discriminant analysis (LDA) classifier has received more and more attention for classifying data of very large dimension under certain sparsity assumptions (Cai and Liu, 2011; Mai, Zou and Yuan, 2012; Fan, Feng and Tong, 2012). In this paper, we will focus on the general case where no sparsity assumption is assumed and study the effect of dimensionality on the performance of LDA and the regularized LDA (Friedman, 1989). For simplicity, we shall focus on the two-class classification problem.

The issue of dimension effect, or more specifically, the effect that a diverging dimension pùëùp would brought to classical statistical inference (Bai, Liu and Wong, 2009), has been studied in several statistical problems in the literature. Bai and Saranadasa (1996) first studied the dimension effect of Hotelling‚Äôs T2superscriptùëá2T^{2} test by deriving the explicit power under local alternatives. Bai, Liu and Wong (2009) and El¬†Karoui (2010) considered the dimension effect of Markowitz‚Äôs portfolio. For LDA, when the dimension pùëùp is assumed to be fixed, many works have been done to study the asymptotic of the misclassification rate by studying the properties of Wishart distribution. For a diverging pùëùp, a seminal work by Bickel and Levina (2004) showed that when p/n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëùùëõp/n\to\infty, LDA tends to random guessing. Shao et¬†al. (2011) proved that when p‚Äãlog‚Å°p/n‚Üí0‚Üíùëùùëùùëõ0p\sqrt{\log{p}}/\sqrt{n}\to 0, LDA is consistent in that the error rate of sample LDA tends to the oracle Bayes error rate. Other related works that handle variations of LDA (for example, quadratic discriminant analysis etc.) can also be found in Saranadasa (1993), Cheng (2004) and Li and Yao (2016), among others. On the other hand, when pùëùp is large, regularization method is commonly used to reduce the dispersion of the sample covariance matrix; see for example Chen et¬†al. (2011) for the study of the regularized Hotelling‚Äôs T2superscriptùëá2T^{2} test and Ledoit and Wolf (2004) for regularized estimation in Markowitz‚Äôs portfolio. Regularization procedure has also been widely applied in many other statistical analysis in current high dimensional literature; see for example Cai, Liu and Luo (2011), B√ºhlmann (2013) and Wang and Leng (2016). For discriminant analysis, the regularized LDA (RLDA) was proposed and studied in Friedman (1989) and Guo, Hastie and Tibshirani (2007). Recently, Zollanvari and Dougherty (2013, 2015) studied the misclassification error rate of RLDA with the motivation to estimate this error rate and moreover, they did not provide explicit expressions for the rate. Dobriban and Wager (2018) analyzed the predictive risk of ridge regression and regularized discriminant analysis and derived some explicit formulas. However, the results were based on the random effects hypothesis which is a strong assumption.

Among these existing literatures, the problem of how the high dimensionality would affect the classification accuracy of LDA and RLDA when the observation dimension pùëùp is of the same order as the sample size nùëõn is still not well understood and in this work we provide a comprehensive analysis of the misclassification error rates under mild conditions. Built on properties of the Wishart distribution, we will first study the dimension effect of LDA (Section 2) under the assumption that p/n‚Üíy‚àà(0,1)‚Üíùëùùëõùë¶01p/n\rightarrow y\in(0,1). In the general case where p/n‚Üíy‚àà(0,‚àû)‚Üíùëùùëõùë¶0p/n\rightarrow y\in(0,\infty), using recent results in random matrix theory, we provide a systematic study on the dimension effect of the RLDA in Section 3. Overall, this paper aims at providing theoretical studies on the dimension effect of LDA and RLDA, from which we gain insights of how the increasing dimension affects the classification accuracy of LDA and RLDA. Following is a summary of the contributions of our work:

  • ‚Ä¢

    For LDA, we study the effect of the sample means and the sample covariance matrix respectively. Interestingly, our results show that the dimension effect brought by the sample means would introduce some bias to LDA, which would be further amplified by the effect brought by the sample covariance matrix. Motivated by these observations, a bias correction is proposed to improve the classification accuracy.

  • ‚Ä¢

    For RLDA, we derive the closed form of the error rates under general cases. Dobriban and Wager (2018) studied a similar question under random effect which is a strong condition. We relax this condition and consider a general case which includes random effect as a special case. Similar to LDA, a bias corrected RLDA is proposed to reduce the bias brought by the dimension effect that improves the classification performance.

  • ‚Ä¢

    To study the dimension effect of RLDA, the key question is to study the asymptotic limits of the moments of a class of random matrices and their random quadratic forms involved of the population means. The former one is studied by Ledoit and P√©ch√© (2011), Chen et¬†al. (2011) and our previous work Wang et¬†al. (2015). When the population means satisfy some special structures such as the eigenvector structures in Bai, Miao and Pan (2007) or the random effect of Dobriban and Wager (2018), the limits of quadratic forms are the same as the moments. By studying the limits of these moments, Dobriban and Wager (2018) derived the dimension effect of RLDA under the random effect assumption. For general cases, the asymptotic of the random quadratic forms are much more challenging. Bai, Liu and Wong (2011) derived results for an identity matrix. El¬†Karoui and Holger (2011) provided a tool to study the limits of the quadratic forms. Based on the methods of El¬†Karoui and Holger (2011), we develop explicit results for the dimension effect of RLDA under mild conditions.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. We study the dimension effect of LDA when p/n‚Üíy‚àà(0,1)‚Üíùëùùëõùë¶01p/n\rightarrow y\in(0,1) in Section 2. Dimension effect of RLDA is provided in Section 3. To better understand the dimension effect of RLDA and verify our theoretical results, we conduct several interesting examples in Section 4 and simulations in Section 5. All technical details are relegated to the Appendix.

To investigate the dimension effect of the sample means and the sample covariance matrix separately, we will first study two simple cases to gain some insights:

  • (i)

    Assuming that Œ£Œ£\Sigma is known, what is the effect brought by the sample mean?

  • (ii)

    Assuming that Œº1,Œº2subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2\mu_{1},\mu_{2} are known, what is the effect brought by the sample covariance matrix?

For convenience, we assume that ŒîŒî\Delta is a constant throughout the paper. As pointed out by Cai and Liu (2011), the case where Œî‚Üí0‚ÜíŒî0\Delta\rightarrow 0 would indicate that no classifier is better than random guessing. Similarly, the case where Œî‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíŒî\Delta\rightarrow\infty would imply that the two classes are so separated that classification is trivial such that even naive Bayes would asymptotically have zero misclassification rate (Aoshima and Yata, 2014).

2.1 Effect of the sample mean

To investigate the effect brought by the sample mean, we first assume Œ£Œ£\Sigma is known and consider the following linear classifier

which is obtained by replacing SnsubscriptùëÜùëõS_{n} in the LDA classifier (2.3) by the true Œ£Œ£\Sigma. The misclassification rate of the above classifier can be computed as:

The dimension effect brought by the sample means can then be characterized by the asymptotic misclassification rate given in the following theorem.

Theorem 2.1.

RLDA1‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚Äã12‚ÄãŒ¶‚Äã(‚àíŒî2+y2‚àíy12‚ÄãŒî2+y1+y2)+12‚ÄãŒ¶‚Äã(‚àíŒî2+y1‚àíy22‚ÄãŒî2+y1+y2).subscriptRLDA1ùëù‚Üí12Œ¶superscriptŒî2subscriptùë¶2subscriptùë¶12superscriptŒî2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶212Œ¶superscriptŒî2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶22superscriptŒî2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶2\displaystyle\mbox{R}_{\text{LDA1}}\overset{p}{\to}\frac{1}{2}\Phi\Bigg{(}-\frac{\Delta^{2}+y_{2}-y_{1}}{2\sqrt{\Delta^{2}+y_{1}+y_{2}}}\Bigg{)}+\frac{1}{2}\Phi\Bigg{(}-\frac{\Delta^{2}+y_{1}-y_{2}}{2\sqrt{\Delta^{2}+y_{1}+y_{2}}}\Bigg{)}. (2.4)

By comparing (2.4) with the optimal Bayes error (2), we can see that the dimension effect brought by the sample means depends on y1,y2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶2y_{1},y_{2} only. From Theorem 2.1 we know that even if Œ£Œ£\Sigma is known, when y1subscriptùë¶1y_{1} or y2subscriptùë¶2y_{2} is very large which indicates that the dimension far more exceeds the sample size, the misclassification rate would tend to 50%percent5050\%. The conclusion is consistent with the one in the seminal paper Bickel and Levina (2004) which studied the dimension effect from a minimax point of view under the setting p/n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëùùëõp/n\to\infty.

2.2 Effect of the sample covariance matrix

Similarly, we study the effect brought by the sample covariance matrix. Assuming the population means Œº1,Œº2subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2\mu_{1},\mu_{2} are known, we consider the classifier

Œ¥LDA2‚Äã(X)=ùïÄ‚Äã{(X‚àíŒº1+Œº22)T‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)>0}.subscriptùõøLDA2ùëãùïÄsuperscriptùëãsubscriptùúá1subscriptùúá22TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá20\displaystyle\delta_{\text{LDA2}}(X)=\mathbb{I}\left\{\left(X-\frac{\mu_{1}+\mu_{2}}{2}\right)^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})>0\right\}.

The corresponding misclassification rate is

RLDA2=Œ¶‚Äã(‚àí(Œº1‚àíŒº2)T‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)2‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)T‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚ÄãŒ£‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)).subscriptRLDA2Œ¶superscriptsubscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá22superscriptsubscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1Œ£superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2\displaystyle\mbox{R}_{\text{LDA2}}=\Phi\left(\frac{-(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})}{2\sqrt{(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}\Sigma S_{n}^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})}}\right).
Theorem 2.2.

Assuming p/(n1+n2)‚Üíy‚àà(0,1)‚Üíùëùsubscriptùëõ1subscriptùëõ2ùë¶01p/(n_{1}+n_{2})\to y\in(0,1), we have,

RLDA2‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚ÄãŒ¶‚Äã(‚àíŒî2‚Äã1‚àíy).subscriptRLDA2ùëù‚ÜíŒ¶Œî21ùë¶\displaystyle\mbox{R}_{\text{LDA2}}\overset{p}{\to}\Phi\left(-\frac{\Delta}{2}\sqrt{1-y}\right). (2.5)

Comparing with the optimal Bayes error (2) we can see that the term 1‚àíy1ùë¶\sqrt{1-y} in (2.5) is exactly the price we pay by using the sample covariance matrix in LDA. Since the results only depend on Wishart distribution, it would be possible to built up more precise results under weaker conditions such as n>p+2ùëõùëù2n>p+2 and p/n‚Üíy‚àà(0,1]‚Üíùëùùëõùë¶01p/n\to y\in(0,1] (Jiang and Yang, 2013) and we leave it to future work. By the properties of Wishart distribution (Cook and Forzani, 2011), we have

E‚ÄãSn‚àí1=n‚àí2n‚àíp‚àí3‚ÄãŒ£‚àí1,E‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚ÄãŒ£‚ÄãSn‚àí1=(n‚àí2)2‚Äã(n‚àí3)(n‚àíp‚àí2)‚Äã(n‚àíp‚àí3)‚Äã(n‚àíp‚àí5)‚ÄãŒ£‚àí1.formulae-sequenceùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1ùëõ2ùëõùëù3superscriptŒ£1ùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1Œ£superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1superscriptùëõ22ùëõ3ùëõùëù2ùëõùëù3ùëõùëù5superscriptŒ£1\displaystyle ES_{n}^{-1}=\frac{n-2}{n-p-3}\Sigma^{-1},~{}ES_{n}^{-1}\Sigma S_{n}^{-1}=\frac{(n-2)^{2}(n-3)}{(n-p-2)(n-p-3)(n-p-5)}\Sigma^{-1}.

Therefore, the term 1‚àíy1ùë¶\sqrt{1-y} is actually introduced by the inverse Wishart distribution. We note 1‚àíy1ùë¶\sqrt{1-y} also arises in the dimension effect for Hotelling‚Äôs test (Pan and Zhou, 2011) or the Markowitz portfolio (Bai, Liu and Wong, 2009; El¬†Karoui, 2010) which both involve the inverse of the sample covariance matrix.

2.3 Dimension effect of LDA

Theorems 2.1 and 2.2 show the explicit results for the sample means and the sample covariance from which we can see the explicit price we pay for the estimation. Now, we present the result for LDA as follows.

Theorem 2.3.

Assuming p/nj‚Üíyj‚àà(0,‚àû),j=1,2formulae-sequence‚Üíùëùsubscriptùëõùëósubscriptùë¶ùëó0ùëó12p/n_{j}\to y_{j}\in(0,\infty),~{}j=1,2 and y=defy1‚Äãy2/(y1+y2)<1superscriptdefùë¶subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶21y\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mbox{{\tiny def}}}}{{=}}y_{1}y_{2}/(y_{1}+y_{2})<1, we have

RLDA‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚Äã12‚Äã‚àëj=12Œ¶‚Äã(‚àíŒî2+(‚àí1)j‚Äã(y1‚àíy2)2‚ÄãŒî2+y1+y2‚Äã1‚àíy).subscriptRLDAùëù‚Üí12superscriptsubscriptùëó12Œ¶superscriptŒî2superscript1ùëósubscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶22superscriptŒî2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶21ùë¶\displaystyle\mbox{R}_{\text{LDA}}\overset{p}{\to}\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^{2}\Phi\left(-\frac{\Delta^{2}+(-1)^{j}(y_{1}-y_{2})}{2\sqrt{\Delta^{2}+y_{1}+y_{2}}}\sqrt{1-y}\right). (2.6)

Note that the term on the right hand side of (2.6) correspond to the misclassification rate within class 1 and class 2 respectively. LDA has different classification performance on the two classes when y1‚â†y2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶2y_{1}\neq y_{2}. From the proof of Theorem 2.1 we can see that this is due to the estimation bias of intercept part in LDA. On the other hand, from (2.5) we learn that the effect from the sample covariance matrix would result in a multiplication factor 1‚àíy1ùë¶\sqrt{1-y}. Interestingly, we show that when both sample means and sample covariance matrix are used as in LDA (2.3), the bias introduced by the sample means was further amplified by the multiplication factor 1‚àíy1ùë¶\sqrt{1-y}.

To investigate the bias of LDA, we consider the classifier,

ùïÄ‚Äã{XT‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)+Œ±>0}.ùïÄsuperscriptùëãTsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2ùõº0\displaystyle\mathbb{I}\left\{X^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})+\alpha>0\right\}. (2.7)

By Proposition 2 of Mai, Zou and Yuan (2012), given the classification direction Sn‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2}) in (2.7), the optimal intercept corresponding to minimum misclassification rate is given as,

Œ±0=‚àí12‚Äã(Œº1+Œº2)T‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2).subscriptùõº012superscriptsubscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2\displaystyle\alpha_{0}=-\frac{1}{2}(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2}).

One the other hand, note that (2.7) would reduce to the LDA classifier (2.3) if the intercept Œ±ùõº\alpha is set to be ‚àí12‚Äã(X¬Ø1+X¬Ø2)T‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2).12superscriptsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2-\frac{1}{2}(\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2}). However, direct calculation shows that,

‚àí12‚ÄãE‚Äã(X¬Ø1+X¬Ø2)T‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)=E‚ÄãŒ±0+n‚àí2n‚àíp‚àí3‚Äã(p2‚Äãn2‚àíp2‚Äãn1),12ùê∏superscriptsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2ùê∏subscriptùõº0ùëõ2ùëõùëù3ùëù2subscriptùëõ2ùëù2subscriptùëõ1\displaystyle-\frac{1}{2}E(\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})=E\alpha_{0}+\frac{n-2}{n-p-3}\Big{(}\frac{p}{2n_{2}}-\frac{p}{2n_{1}}\Big{)},

which indicates that the expected bias between the intercept of LDA and the optimal intercept Œ±0subscriptùõº0\alpha_{0} is exactly n‚àí2n‚àíp‚àí3‚Äã(p2‚Äãn2‚àíp2‚Äãn1)ùëõ2ùëõùëù3ùëù2subscriptùëõ2ùëù2subscriptùëõ1\frac{n-2}{n-p-3}\big{(}\frac{p}{2n_{2}}-\frac{p}{2n_{1}}\big{)}. We thus can make a bias correction to LDA as follow,

Œ¥LDAc‚Äã(X)=ùïÄ‚Äã{(X‚àíX¬Ø1+X¬Ø22)T‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)+n‚àí2n‚àíp‚àí3‚Äã(p2‚Äãn1‚àíp2‚Äãn2)>0}.superscriptsubscriptùõøLDAùëêùëãùïÄsuperscriptùëãsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã22TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2ùëõ2ùëõùëù3ùëù2subscriptùëõ1ùëù2subscriptùëõ20\displaystyle\delta_{\text{LDA}}^{c}(X)=\mathbb{I}\left\{\Big{(}X-\frac{\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2}}{2}\Big{)}^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})+\frac{n-2}{n-p-3}\Big{(}\frac{p}{2n_{1}}-\frac{p}{2n_{2}}\Big{)}>0\right\}. (2.8)

Let RLDAcsuperscriptsubscriptRLDAùëê\mbox{R}_{\text{LDA}}^{c} be the misclassification rate of the bias-corrected classifier (2.8). The following proposition gives the asymptotic misclassification rate of the above bias-corrected classifier.

Proposition 2.1.

Under the conditions of Theorem 2.3,

RLDAc‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚ÄãŒ¶‚Äã(‚àíŒî22‚ÄãŒî2+y1+y2‚Äã1‚àíy).superscriptsubscriptRLDAùëêùëù‚ÜíŒ¶superscriptŒî22superscriptŒî2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶21ùë¶\displaystyle\mbox{R}_{\text{LDA}}^{c}\overset{p}{\to}\Phi\left(-\frac{\Delta^{2}}{2\sqrt{\Delta^{2}+y_{1}+y_{2}}}\sqrt{1-y}\right). (2.9)

By noticing that Œ¶‚Äã(x)Œ¶ùë•\Phi(x) is strictly convex in x‚àà(‚àí‚àû,0)ùë•0x\in(-\infty,0), we immediately have that the asymptotic misclassification rate of the bias corrected LDA given in (2.9) is smaller than the asymptotic misclassification rate of LDA given in (2.6). In addition, considering the linear classifier with optimal intercept,

ùïÄ‚Äã{XT‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)‚àí12‚Äã(Œº1+Œº2)T‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)>0}.ùïÄsuperscriptùëãTsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã212superscriptsubscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã20\displaystyle\mathbb{I}\left\{X^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})-\frac{1}{2}(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})>0\right\}.

It can be shown that the result given in (2.9) would also hold for this oracle classifier, indicating that our bias correction procedure does eliminate the bias introduced by the unequal sample sizes. Finally, we remark that bias issues in binary classification have received much attention in early literatures; see for example Chan and Hall (2009) and Huang, Tong and Zhao (2010) and the references therein. For LDA, the bias-corrected classifier (2.8) happens to be identical to formula (8) of Moran and Murphy (1979). Our motivation and interpretation provide a different view on (2.8) and theoretical justifications provided in Proposition 2.1 are also new.

In literature, to handle high dimension data, naive Bayes (Dudoit, Fridlyand and Speed, 2002; Bickel and Levina, 2004) and sparse LDA (Cai and Liu, 2011; Mai, Zou and Yuan, 2012; Fan, Feng and Tong, 2012) were proposed. For naive Bayes, the correlation between the covariates is ignored and only the diagonal elements of the sample covariance matrix are used. Sparse LDA methods assumed that the discriminant direction Œ≤=Œ£‚àí1‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)ùõΩsuperscriptŒ£1subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2\beta=\Sigma^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}) is sparse in that only several elements in Œ≤ùõΩ\beta are non-zero and others are either zero or close to zero. In the following remarks we provide some comparison of the LDA rule to the naive Bayes rule and sparse LDA approaches.

Remark 2.1.

For simplicity, we consider the homogeneous case where the diagonal elements of Œ£Œ£\Sigma equal to each other and assume that n1=n2subscriptùëõ1subscriptùëõ2n_{1}=n_{2}. Consider the following naive Bayes classification rule,

Œ¥NB‚Äã(X)=ùïÄ‚Äã{(X‚àíX¬Ø1+X¬Ø22)T‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)>0}.subscriptùõøNBùëãùïÄsuperscriptùëãsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã22Tsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã20\displaystyle\delta_{\text{NB}}(X)=\mathbb{I}\left\{\left(X-\frac{\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2}}{2}\right)^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})>0\right\}.

The conditional misclassification rate of Œ¥NB‚Äã(X)subscriptùõøNBùëã\delta_{\text{NB}}(X) is

RNB=12‚Äã‚àëj=12Œ¶‚Äã((‚àí1)j‚Äã(Œºj‚àíX¬Ø1+X¬Ø22)T‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)T‚ÄãŒ£‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)).subscriptRNB12superscriptsubscriptùëó12Œ¶superscript1ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëósubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã22Tsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2superscriptsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2TŒ£subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2\displaystyle\mbox{R}_{\text{NB}}=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^{2}\Phi\left(\frac{(-1)^{j}\left(\mu_{j}-\frac{\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2}}{2}\right)^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})}{\sqrt{(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}\Sigma(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})}}\right).

By a similar analysis as our proofs for Theorem 2.3, we have

RNB=Œ¶‚Äã(‚àí(Œº1‚àíŒº2)T‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)+op‚Äã(1)2‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)T‚ÄãŒ£‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)+4n‚Äãtr‚Äã(Œ£2)+op‚Äã(1)).subscriptRNBŒ¶superscriptsubscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2Tsubscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2subscriptùëúùëù12superscriptsubscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2TŒ£subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá24ùëõtrsuperscriptŒ£2subscriptùëúùëù1\displaystyle\mbox{R}_{\text{NB}}=\Phi\left(-\frac{(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})+o_{p}(1)}{2\sqrt{(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}\Sigma(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})+\frac{4}{n}\mbox{tr}(\Sigma^{2})}+o_{p}(1)}\right).

We can see that the performance of naive Bayes depends on the structure of Œ£Œ£\Sigma. When Œ£=œÉ2‚ÄãIpŒ£superscriptùúé2subscriptùêºùëù\Sigma=\sigma^{2}I_{p} for some constant œÉ2>0superscriptùúé20\sigma^{2}>0, comparing with (2.6), the asymptotic error rate of the naive Bayes rule is the same as that of LDA except the term 1‚àíy1ùë¶\sqrt{1-y}, indicating that naive Bayes is always better than LDA. When the off diagonal elements of Œ£Œ£\Sigma are nonzero, we would need to pay some price for wrongly ignoring the correlations. A simulation study will be conducted in Section 5, providing further numerical comparison between naive Bayes and LDA.

Remark 2.2.

For sparse LDA, we take the linear programming discriminant (LPD) rule as an example which was proposed by Cai and Liu (2011). The LPD rule estimates the discriminant direction by solving the following optimization problem,

Œ≤^=arg‚Å°min‚Å°|Œ≤|1,subject¬†to¬†‚Äã|Sn‚ÄãŒ≤‚àí(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)|‚àû‚â§tn,formulae-sequence^ùõΩsubscriptùõΩ1subject¬†to¬†subscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõùõΩsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2subscriptùë°ùëõ\displaystyle\hat{\beta}=\arg\min|\beta|_{1},~{}\mbox{subject~{}to~{}}|S_{n}\beta-(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})|_{\infty}\leq t_{n},

where tnsubscriptùë°ùëõt_{n} is a tuning parameter. Under regular conditions, the misclassification rate RLPDsubscriptùëÖLPDR_{\text{LPD}} of LPD (Cai and Liu, 2011, Theorem 3) satisfies,

RLPDŒ¶‚Äã(‚àíŒî/2)‚àí1=Op‚Äã(Œî2‚Äãs‚Äãlog‚Å°pn).subscriptùëÖLPDŒ¶Œî21subscriptùëÇùëùsuperscriptŒî2ùë†ùëùùëõ\displaystyle\frac{R_{\text{LPD}}}{\Phi(-\Delta/2)}-1=O_{p}\left(\Delta^{2}s\sqrt{\frac{\log{p}}{n}}\right).

where sùë†s is the number of non-zero elements of Œ£‚àí1‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)superscriptŒ£1subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2\Sigma^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}). Unlike LDA, the misclassification rate of LPD not only depends on pùëùp and nùëõn, but also hinge on the size of sùë†s. When sùë†s is small, LPD will achieve a good performance and even close to the Bayes rule while the dimension pùëùp is allowed to grow exponentially in nùëõn. However, when the sparsity assumption is violated, it is expected that LPD will perform poor if sùë†s is large. Further numerical comparison will be provided in Section 5.

3 Regularized Linear Discriminant Analysis

RLDA (Friedman, 1989; Guo, Hastie and Tibshirani, 2007) was proposed to reduce the dispersion of eigenvalues of the sample covariance matrix when pùëùp is large and overcome the singularity issue when p>n‚àí2ùëùùëõ2p>n-2. For a given tuning parameter Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0, the RLDA classifier is given as,

Œ¥RLDA‚Äã(X)=ùïÄ‚Äã{(X‚àíX¬Ø1+X¬Ø22)T‚Äã(Sn+Œª‚ÄãIp)‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)>0}.subscriptùõøRLDAùëãùïÄsuperscriptùëãsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã22TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõùúÜsubscriptùêºùëù1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã20\displaystyle\delta_{\text{RLDA}}(X)=\mathbb{I}\left\{\left(X-\frac{\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2}}{2}\right)^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})>0\right\}.

When SnsubscriptùëÜùëõS_{n} is invertible, RLDA would reduce to LDA if ŒªùúÜ\lambda is set to be zero. With one more degree of freedom to adjust the estimation of the covariance matrix, it is well known that RLDA generally poses better performance than LDA, providing that ŒªùúÜ\lambda is chosen properly. The misclassification rate of RLDA is

RRLDA‚Äã(Œª)=12‚Äã‚àëj=12Œ¶‚Äã((‚àí1)j‚Äã(Œºj‚àíX¬Ø1+X¬Ø22)T‚Äã(Sn+Œª‚ÄãIp)‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)T‚Äã(Sn+Œª‚ÄãIp)‚àí1‚ÄãŒ£‚Äã(Sn+Œª‚ÄãIp)‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)).subscriptRRLDAùúÜ12superscriptsubscriptùëó12Œ¶superscript1ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëósubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã22TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõùúÜsubscriptùêºùëù1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2superscriptsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõùúÜsubscriptùêºùëù1Œ£superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõùúÜsubscriptùêºùëù1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2\displaystyle\mbox{R}_{\text{RLDA}}(\lambda)=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^{2}\Phi\left(\frac{(-1)^{j}\left(\mu_{j}-\frac{\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2}}{2}\right)^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})}{\sqrt{(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}\Sigma(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})}}\right).

To explore the dimension effect on RLDA, we need to study the asymptotic properties of RRLDA‚Äã(Œª)subscriptRRLDAùúÜ\mbox{R}_{\text{RLDA}}(\lambda). Denote

(3.1)

By noticing that

Here, we study the problem under more general settings where no structure on Œº1,Œº2subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2\mu_{1},\mu_{2} is assumed. Following is our main results.

3.1 Dimension effect of RLDA

Theorem 3.1.

Under the conditions (C1)-(C3), for any Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0,

Theorem 3.1 provides an explicit expression for the asymptotic misclassification rate of RLDA, which characterizes the effect of the data dimension in terms of y1,y2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶2y_{1},y_{2} and the functions on the regularization parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambda defined above.

Remark 3.1.

From the proof of Theorem 3.1, we note that when y<1ùë¶1y<1 and Œª=0ùúÜ0\lambda=0, (3.5) reduces to (2.6), implying that Theorem 2.3 could be regarded as a special case of Theorem 3.1. We remark that the proof of Theorem 2.3 is built on properties of normal and Wishart distributions only while Theorem 3.1 is built on the more complicated random matrix theory.

By noticing that if

h1‚Äã(t)=‚à´xx+t‚ÄãùëëH‚Äã(x),h2‚Äã(t)=‚à´x2(x+t)2‚ÄãùëëH‚Äã(x),formulae-sequencesubscript‚Ñé1ùë°ùë•ùë•ùë°differential-dùêªùë•subscript‚Ñé2ùë°superscriptùë•2superscriptùë•ùë°2differential-dùêªùë•\displaystyle h_{1}(t)=\int\frac{x}{x+t}dH(x),~{}h_{2}(t)=\int\frac{x^{2}}{(x+t)^{2}}dH(x), (3.6)

we would have H1‚Äã(Œª)=R1‚Äã(Œª),H2‚Äã(Œª)=R2‚Äã(Œª)formulae-sequencesubscriptùêª1ùúÜsubscriptùëÖ1ùúÜsubscriptùêª2ùúÜsubscriptùëÖ2ùúÜH_{1}(\lambda)=R_{1}(\lambda),H_{2}(\lambda)=R_{2}(\lambda) and hence the asymptotic misclassification rate (3.5) can be further simplified. This is summarized in the following proposition.

Proposition 3.1.

Under the conditions of Theorem 3.1 and assuming that (3.6) holds, we have

RRLDA‚Äã(Œª)‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚Äã12‚Äã‚àëj=12Œ¶‚Äã(‚àíŒî2+(‚àí1)j‚Äã(y1‚àíy2)2‚ÄãŒî2+y1+y2‚ÄãR1‚Äã(Œª)R2‚Äã(Œª)).subscriptRRLDAùúÜùëù‚Üí12superscriptsubscriptùëó12Œ¶superscriptŒî2superscript1ùëósubscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶22superscriptŒî2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶2subscriptùëÖ1ùúÜsubscriptùëÖ2ùúÜ\displaystyle\mbox{R}_{\text{RLDA}}(\lambda)\overset{p}{\to}\frac{1}{2}\ \sum_{j=1}^{2}\Phi\left(-\frac{\Delta^{2}+(-1)^{j}(y_{1}-y_{2})}{2\sqrt{\Delta^{2}+y_{1}+y_{2}}}\frac{R_{1}(\lambda)}{\sqrt{R_{2}(\lambda)}}\right).

Note that condition (3.6) would hold when Œº1‚àíŒº2subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2\mu_{1}-\mu_{2} and Œ£Œ£\Sigma satisfy the following structures,

A trivial example satisfies the above structure is Œ£=IpŒ£subscriptùêºùëù\Sigma=I_{p} and an interesting isotropic example will also be discussed in Section 4.

3.2 Bias correction for RLDA

To reduce the bias brought by the unequal sample sizes, following the same idea of bias correction for LDA as in Section 2.3, we consider the following class of classifiers,

ùïÄ‚Äã{XT‚Äã(Sn+Œª‚ÄãIp)‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)+Œ±>0}.ùïÄsuperscriptùëãTsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõùúÜsubscriptùêºùëù1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2ùõº0\displaystyle\mathbb{I}\left\{X^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})+\alpha>0\right\}.

Given the discriminant direction (Sn+Œª‚ÄãIp)‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõùúÜsubscriptùêºùëù1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2}), the optimal intercept corresponding to minimum misclassification rate is given as,

while for RLDA the intercept is ‚àí12‚Äã(X¬Ø1+X¬Ø2)T‚Äã(Sn+Œª‚ÄãIp)‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2).12superscriptsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõùúÜsubscriptùêºùëù1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2-\frac{1}{2}(\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2}). On the other hand, from the proof of Theorem 3.1 we have

‚àí12‚ÄãE‚Äã(X¬Ø1+X¬Ø2)T‚Äã(Sn+Œª‚ÄãIp)‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)12ùê∏superscriptsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõùúÜsubscriptùêºùëù1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2\displaystyle-\frac{1}{2}E(\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})
=\displaystyle= E‚ÄãŒ±r+E‚Äã12‚Äãn1‚ÄãY1T‚ÄãBn‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãY1‚àíE‚Äã12‚Äãn2‚ÄãY2T‚ÄãBn‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãY2ùê∏subscriptùõºùëüùê∏12subscriptùëõ1superscriptsubscriptùëå1TsubscriptùêµùëõùúÜsubscriptùëå1ùê∏12subscriptùëõ2superscriptsubscriptùëå2TsubscriptùêµùëõùúÜsubscriptùëå2\displaystyle E\alpha_{r}+E\frac{1}{2n_{1}}Y_{1}^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}B_{n}(\lambda)Y_{1}-E\frac{1}{2n_{2}}Y_{2}^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}B_{n}(\lambda)Y_{2}
=\displaystyle= E‚ÄãŒ±r‚àí(p2‚Äãn1‚àíp2‚Äãn2)‚ÄãE‚Äãtr‚Äã(Bn‚Äã(Œª))p.ùê∏subscriptùõºùëüùëù2subscriptùëõ1ùëù2subscriptùëõ2ùê∏trsubscriptùêµùëõùúÜùëù\displaystyle E\alpha_{r}-\left(\frac{p}{2n_{1}}-\frac{p}{2n_{2}}\right)\frac{E\mbox{tr}(B_{n}(\lambda))}{p}.

Therefore, we can correct the bias as follow,

(3.7)

Proposition 3.2.

Under the conditions of Theorem 3.1,

RRLDAc‚Äã(Œª)‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚ÄãŒ¶‚Äã(‚àíH1‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒî22‚ÄãH2‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒî2+(y1+y2)‚ÄãR2‚Äã(Œª)).subscriptsuperscriptRùëêRLDAùúÜùëù‚ÜíŒ¶subscriptùêª1ùúÜsuperscriptŒî22subscriptùêª2ùúÜsuperscriptŒî2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶2subscriptùëÖ2ùúÜ\displaystyle\mbox{R}^{c}_{\text{RLDA}}(\lambda)\overset{p}{\to}\Phi\left(-\frac{H_{1}(\lambda)\Delta^{2}}{2\sqrt{H_{2}(\lambda)\Delta^{2}+(y_{1}+y_{2})R_{2}(\lambda)}}\right). (3.8)

Again by the convexity of Œ¶‚Äã(x)Œ¶ùë•\Phi(x) in x‚àà(‚àí‚àû,0)ùë•0x\in(-\infty,0), we conclude that the asymptotic misclassification rate of the bias corrected RLDA given in (3.8) is smaller than the asymptotic misclassification rate of RLDA given in (3.5). Similarly to the bias correction for LDA, we can claim the result of (3.8) is also the asymptotic error rate of RLDA with optimal intercept.

3.3 Selection of ŒªùúÜ\lambda

From the perspective of applications, the RLDA can avoid the singularity problem of SnsubscriptùëÜùëõS_{n} when p>nùëùùëõp>n and provides a better performance than LDA even if p<nùëùùëõp<n. However, the performance of RLDA relies on the choice of the regularization parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambda. Empirically, we can use re-sampling procedures such as cross validation to choose ŒªùúÜ\lambda. However, there is little work on the theoretical analysis of these re-sampling procedures, and cross validation can be computationally expensive when both pùëùp and nùëõn are large. In this section, we discuss the effect of ŒªùúÜ\lambda on the misclassification error rate and provide a direct estimation of the optimal ŒªùúÜ\lambda for the special cases.

By Proposition 3.2, the optimal ŒªùúÜ\lambda with minimum error rate is

Œª0‚ààarg‚Å°max‚Å°H1‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒî2H2‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒî2+(y1+y2)‚ÄãR2‚Äã(Œª).subscriptùúÜ0subscriptùêª1ùúÜsuperscriptŒî2subscriptùêª2ùúÜsuperscriptŒî2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶2subscriptùëÖ2ùúÜ\displaystyle\lambda_{0}\in\arg\max\frac{H_{1}(\lambda)\Delta^{2}}{\sqrt{H_{2}(\lambda)\Delta^{2}+(y_{1}+y_{2})R_{2}(\lambda)}}. (3.9)

From the definitions of H1‚Äã(Œª)subscriptùêª1ùúÜH_{1}(\lambda) and H2‚Äã(Œª)subscriptùêª2ùúÜH_{2}(\lambda), these parameters depend on the true structures of Œ£Œ£\Sigma and Œºùúá\mu and it is not easy to construct estimations for them. However, under the assumption of Proposition 3.1, the optimal ŒªùúÜ\lambda has a simple form

Œª0‚ààarg‚Å°max‚Å°R12‚Äã(Œª)R2‚Äã(Œª).subscriptùúÜ0subscriptsuperscriptùëÖ21ùúÜsubscriptùëÖ2ùúÜ\displaystyle\lambda_{0}\in\arg\max\frac{R^{2}_{1}(\lambda)}{R_{2}(\lambda)}.

This motivates us to select Œª0subscriptùúÜ0\lambda_{0} by maximizing an estimate of R12‚Äã(Œª)/R2‚Äã(Œª)subscriptsuperscriptùëÖ21ùúÜsubscriptùëÖ2ùúÜ{R^{2}_{1}(\lambda)}/{R_{2}(\lambda)}. As discussed before, R1‚Äã(Œª)subscriptùëÖ1ùúÜR_{1}(\lambda) and R2‚Äã(Œª)subscriptùëÖ2ùúÜR_{2}(\lambda) only depends on the eigenvalues of Œ£Œ£\Sigma and could be estimated by the eigenvalues of SnsubscriptùëÜùëõS_{n}. minŒ±‚Å°1p‚Äãtr‚Äã(Œ±‚Äã(Sn+Œª‚ÄãIp)‚àí1‚ÄãŒ£‚àíIp)2‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚Äã1‚àíR12‚Äã(Œª)R2‚Äã(Œª).subscriptùõº1ùëùtrsuperscriptùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõùúÜsubscriptùêºùëù1Œ£subscriptùêºùëù2ùëù‚Üí1subscriptsuperscriptùëÖ21ùúÜsubscriptùëÖ2ùúÜ\displaystyle\min_{\alpha}\frac{1}{p}\mbox{tr}(\alpha(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}\Sigma-I_{p})^{2}\overset{p}{\to}1-\frac{R^{2}_{1}(\lambda)}{R_{2}(\lambda)}.

Therefore, similar to Wang et¬†al. (2015), we estimate the tuning parameter by

where

Following our previous work Wang et¬†al. (2015), it could be possible to establish some theoretical analysis of the estimation Œª^0subscript^ùúÜ0\hat{\lambda}_{0} under the conditions given in the formula (3.6). For general Œ£,Œº1,Œº2Œ£subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2\Sigma,\mu_{1},\mu_{2}, theoretically it is hard to conduct such an effective estimation. Therefore, we skip the theoretical analysis of the proposed tuning parameter estimation and conduct simulations in Section 5, to compare the Œª^0subscript^ùúÜ0\hat{\lambda}_{0} proposed above with the one obtained by cross validations.

By the Stieltjes transformation of the MP law (see Bai and Silverstein, 2010, Section 3.3), we have,

4.2 Isotropic case

Given the eigenvectors v1,‚ãØ,vpsubscriptùë£1‚ãØsubscriptùë£ùëùv_{1},\cdots,v_{p}, we consider three different isotropic cases

Œº1‚àíŒº2‚àù1p‚Äã(v1+‚ãØ+vp),proportional-tosubscriptùúá1subscriptùúá21ùëùsubscriptùë£1‚ãØsubscriptùë£ùëù\displaystyle\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}\propto\frac{1}{\sqrt{p}}(v_{1}+\cdots+v_{p}), (4.1)
Œ£‚àí1/2‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)‚àù1p‚Äã(v1+‚ãØ+vp),proportional-tosuperscriptŒ£12subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá21ùëùsubscriptùë£1‚ãØsubscriptùë£ùëù\displaystyle\Sigma^{-1/2}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})\propto\frac{1}{\sqrt{p}}(v_{1}+\cdots+v_{p}), (4.2)
Œ£‚àí1‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)‚àù1p‚Äã(v1+‚ãØ+vp).proportional-tosuperscriptŒ£1subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá21ùëùsubscriptùë£1‚ãØsubscriptùë£ùëù\displaystyle\Sigma^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})\propto\frac{1}{\sqrt{p}}(v_{1}+\cdots+v_{p}). (4.3)

In statistics, these cases have different implications. (4.1) implies that the direct differences between the two population means, (4.2) indicates the differences after covariance standardization, and (4.3) implies that the true classification weights. Similar mean-covariance structures also arise in Cai, Liu and Xia (2014) for the testing problem H0:Œº1=Œº2:subscriptùêª0subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2H_{0}:\mu_{1}=\mu_{2}. In random matrix theory, Bai, Miao and Pan (2007) considered (4.1) when studying the asymptotic property of the eigenvectors and more details can be found in their Remark 1.

To illustrate the results, we consider a toy example Œ£=(œÅ|i‚àíj|)p√ópŒ£subscriptsuperscriptùúåùëñùëóùëùùëù\Sigma=(\rho^{|i-j|})_{p\times p} with |œÅ|<1ùúå1|\rho|<1. The covariance matrix Œ£Œ£\Sigma is related to a stationary AR(1) process and is also used in Bickel and Levina (2004) for LDA. By the Szeg√∂ theorem, we have,

We can see from Figure 3 that the dimension effects have different performances for each vksubscriptùë£ùëòv_{k} and the tuning parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambda brings in different effects on the misclassification error rate. For all the simulations, the theoretical misclassification rates are consistent with the empirical ones.

5 Simulations

In this section, we conduct several simulations to illustrate the results. We consider the covariance matrix structures as follows:

Œ£=(œÅ|i‚àíj|)p√óp,Œ£subscriptsuperscriptùúåùëñùëóùëùùëù\displaystyle\Sigma=(\rho^{|i-j|})_{p\times p},

where œÅùúå\rho reflects the correlations between the covariates and |œÅ|<1ùúå1|\rho|<1. For all of our simulations, we let Œº2=0subscriptùúá20\mu_{2}=0 and rescale Œº1subscriptùúá1\mu_{1} to control the Bayes error rate as 10%percent1010\%. Here we fix the sample size n=200ùëõ200n=200 and all the results are based on 100 replications.

5.1 Bias correction for LDA and RLDA

When n1‚â†n2subscriptùëõ1subscriptùëõ2n_{1}\neq n_{2}, we propose a bias correction procedure to the intercept part for LDA and RLDA. Specially, we have

Œ¥LDAc‚Äã(X)=ùïÄ‚Äã{(X‚àíX¬Ø1+X¬Ø22)T‚ÄãSn‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)+n‚àí2n‚àíp‚àí3‚Äã(p2‚Äãn1‚àíp2‚Äãn2)>0},superscriptsubscriptùõøLDAùëêùëãùïÄsuperscriptùëãsubscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã22TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõ1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2ùëõ2ùëõùëù3ùëù2subscriptùëõ1ùëù2subscriptùëõ20\displaystyle\delta_{\text{LDA}}^{c}(X)=\mathbb{I}\left\{\Big{(}X-\frac{\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2}}{2}\Big{)}^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}S_{n}^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})+\frac{n-2}{n-p-3}\Big{(}\frac{p}{2n_{1}}-\frac{p}{2n_{2}}\Big{)}>0\right\},

and

Œ¥RLDAc‚Äã(X)=ùïÄsubscriptsuperscriptùõøùëêRLDAùëãùïÄ\displaystyle\delta^{c}_{\text{RLDA}}(X)=\mathbb{I} {(X‚àíX¬Ø1+X¬Ø22)T(Sn+ŒªIp)‚àí1(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2)\displaystyle\bigg{\{}\left(X-\frac{\bar{X}_{1}+\bar{X}_{2}}{2}\right)^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2})
+(p2‚Äãn1‚àíp2‚Äãn2)1‚àí1p‚Äãt‚Äãr‚Äã(1Œª‚ÄãSn+Ip)‚àí11‚àípn‚àí2+1n‚àí2‚Äãt‚Äãr‚Äã(1Œª‚ÄãSn+Ip)‚àí1>0},Œª>0.\displaystyle+\left(\frac{p}{2n_{1}}-\frac{p}{2n_{2}}\right)\frac{1-\frac{1}{p}tr(\frac{1}{\lambda}S_{n}+I_{p})^{-1}}{1-\frac{p}{n-2}+\frac{1}{n-2}tr(\frac{1}{\lambda}S_{n}+I_{p})^{-1}}>0\bigg{\}},~{}\lambda>0.

Our first simulation is to show the performance of the bias-corrected LDA and RLDA. We fix n=200ùëõ200n=200 and let n1subscriptùëõ1n_{1} rang from 10 to 190. We set ŒªùúÜ\lambda as 0 (which corresponds to LDA), 0.1 and 0.5 for p<nùëùùëõp<n and 0.1, 0.5 and 1 when p‚â•nùëùùëõp\geq n .The data dimension pùëùp is set to be 100, 200 or 400. As a benchmark, we also include the linear classifier with optimal constant

Œ±r=‚àí12‚Äã(Œº1+Œº2)T‚Äã(Sn+Œª‚ÄãIp)‚àí1‚Äã(X¬Ø1‚àíX¬Ø2),subscriptùõºùëü12superscriptsubscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2TsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëõùúÜsubscriptùêºùëù1subscript¬Øùëã1subscript¬Øùëã2\displaystyle\alpha_{r}=-\frac{1}{2}(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2})^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}(S_{n}+\lambda I_{p})^{-1}(\bar{X}_{1}-\bar{X}_{2}),

which is denoted by O-RLDA. We set Œ£=(0.5|i‚àíj|)p√ópŒ£subscriptsuperscript0.5ùëñùëóùëùùëù\Sigma=(0.5^{|i-j|})_{p\times p} and Œº1‚àù(1,0,‚ãØ,0)proportional-tosubscriptùúá110‚ãØ0\mu_{1}\propto(1,0,\cdots,0), and all the simulation results are plotted in Figure 4. We can observe that the bias corrected RLDA (C-RLDA) achieves less misclassification rate than the original RLDA and also the performance of C-RLDA is quite close the one of RLDA with optimal constants. Specially, the first figure of Figure 4 is the results for LDA where p=100,n=200formulae-sequenceùëù100ùëõ200p=100,~{}n=200. We also conduct simulations for more covariance and mean structures and the results follow similar patterns.

5.2 Dimension effect of LDA, naive Bayes and RLDA

In this work, our main focus is to explicitly derive the dimension effects for LDA and RLDA. In detail, the asymptotic misclassification rate of LDA depends on the ratios p/n1,p/n2ùëùsubscriptùëõ1ùëùsubscriptùëõ2p/n_{1},p/n_{2} and the one of RLDA also involves the structure of the covariance the means. More details can be found in Proposition 2.1 and 3.2. In Remark 2.1, we derive the dimension effect for naive Bayes. Here, we conduct a comprehensive comparison for LDA, naive Bayes and RLDA. For Œº1subscriptùúá1\mu_{1}, we consider three scenarios:

  • Case 1: Œº1‚àù(1,0,‚ãØ,0)proportional-tosubscriptùúá110‚ãØ0\mu_{1}\propto(1,0,\cdots,0);

  • Case 2: 10 % elements of Œº1subscriptùúá1\mu_{1} are from N‚Äã(0,1)ùëÅ01N(0,1);

  • Case 3: all the elements of Œº1subscriptùúá1\mu_{1} are from N‚Äã(0,1)ùëÅ01N(0,1);

and for each case we still rescale Œº1subscriptùúá1\mu_{1} to control the Bayes error rate to be 10%. All the results are presented in Figure 5. For each heat map of the error rate, the horizontal is the data dimension pùëùp ranging from 10 to 190 for LDA or 400 for naive Bayes and RLDA. The vertical is the correlation œÅùúå\rho ranging from -0.9 to 0.9. When the data dimension pùëùp is increased, the misclassification rates for all the classifiers also increases which is well understood. When the correlations |œÅ|ùúå|\rho| ranges from 0 to 0.9, the performance of LDA almost has no changes and Naive Bayes gets worse and worse. For RLDA, the performance is affected by |œÅ|ùúå|\rho|, but is less sensitive than naive Bayes.

5.3 RLDA and sparse LDA

In this part, we compare RLDA with the LPD (Cai and Liu, 2011) which is one of sparse LDA methods. The tuning parameters are chosen by 5-folds cross validation. We also include the RLDA where ŒªnsubscriptùúÜùëõ\lambda_{n} is estimated by our method in Section 3.3 and the naive Bayes. In summary, we have four methods NB, LPD, RLDA-CV and RLDA. We control the sparsity level as

Œ£‚àí1‚Äã(Œº1‚àíŒº2)‚àù(rnorm(s),0,‚ãØ,0);proportional-tosuperscriptŒ£1subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2rnorm(s)0‚ãØ0\displaystyle\Sigma^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})\propto(\mbox{rnorm(s)},0,\cdots,0);

with rnorm(s) represent sùë†s random variables generated independently from N‚Äã(0,1)ùëÅ01N(0,1), and in this study sùë†s is increased from 5 to pùëùp. Figure 6 presents the simulation results. We observe that when sùë†s is small, LPD is outstanding with the least error rates and the performance becomes poorer and poorer when sùë†s increases, while RLDA and NB are robust to different sùë†s. Furthermore, we find out that the version with estimated tuning parameter is comparable to the one with cross validation. Overall, we claim that LPD is applicable to the sparse cases while RLDA is favorable to the dense cases.

(7.5)

The proof is completed.

ŒºT‚ÄãBn‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒº‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚ÄãH1‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒî2,ŒºT‚ÄãBn2‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒº‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚ÄãH2‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒî2.superscriptùúáTsubscriptùêµùëõùúÜùúáùëù‚Üísubscriptùêª1ùúÜsuperscriptŒî2superscriptùúáTsubscriptsuperscriptùêµ2ùëõùúÜùúáùëù‚Üísubscriptùêª2ùúÜsuperscriptŒî2\displaystyle\mu^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}B_{n}(\lambda)\mu\overset{p}{\to}H_{1}(\lambda)\Delta^{2},~{}\mu^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}B^{2}_{n}(\lambda)\mu\overset{p}{\to}H_{2}(\lambda)\Delta^{2}.

For the cross sectional terms,

E‚Äã{1nj‚ÄãŒºT‚ÄãBn‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãYj}2=1nj‚ÄãE‚ÄãŒºT‚ÄãBn2‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒº‚â§Œî2‚Äã‚ÄñŒ£‚Äñ2nj‚ÄãŒª2‚Üí0,ùê∏superscript1subscriptùëõùëósuperscriptùúáTsubscriptùêµùëõùúÜsubscriptùëåùëó21subscriptùëõùëóùê∏superscriptùúáTsubscriptsuperscriptùêµ2ùëõùúÜùúásuperscriptŒî2superscriptnormŒ£2subscriptùëõùëósuperscriptùúÜ2‚Üí0\displaystyle E\Big{\{}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n_{j}}}\mu^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}B_{n}(\lambda)Y_{j}\Big{\}}^{2}=\frac{1}{n_{j}}E\mu^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}B^{2}_{n}(\lambda)\mu\leq\frac{\Delta^{2}\|\Sigma\|^{2}}{n_{j}\lambda^{2}}\to 0,

and similarly,

E‚Äã{1n‚ÄãŒºT‚ÄãBn2‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãY1}2=1n‚ÄãE‚ÄãŒºT‚ÄãBn4‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒº‚â§Œî2‚Äã‚ÄñŒ£‚Äñ4nj‚ÄãŒª4‚Üí0.ùê∏superscript1ùëõsuperscriptùúáTsubscriptsuperscriptùêµ2ùëõùúÜsubscriptùëå121ùëõùê∏superscriptùúáTsubscriptsuperscriptùêµ4ùëõùúÜùúásuperscriptŒî2superscriptnormŒ£4subscriptùëõùëósuperscriptùúÜ4‚Üí0\displaystyle E\Big{\{}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\mu^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}B^{2}_{n}(\lambda)Y_{1}\Big{\}}^{2}=\frac{1}{n}E\mu^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}B^{4}_{n}(\lambda)\mu\leq\frac{\Delta^{2}\|\Sigma\|^{4}}{n_{j}\lambda^{4}}\to 0.

Thus,

1n1‚ÄãŒºT‚ÄãBn‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãY1,1n2‚ÄãŒºT‚ÄãBn‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãY2,1n1+1n2‚ÄãŒºT‚ÄãBn2‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãY1‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚Äã0.1subscriptùëõ1superscriptùúáTsubscriptùêµùëõùúÜsubscriptùëå11subscriptùëõ2superscriptùúáTsubscriptùêµùëõùúÜsubscriptùëå21subscriptùëõ11subscriptùëõ2superscriptùúáTsubscriptsuperscriptùêµ2ùëõùúÜsubscriptùëå1ùëù‚Üí0\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sqrt{n_{1}}}\mu^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}B_{n}(\lambda)Y_{1},\frac{1}{\sqrt{n_{2}}}\mu^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}B_{n}(\lambda)Y_{2},\sqrt{\frac{1}{n_{1}}+\frac{1}{n_{2}}}\mu^{\mbox{\tiny{T}}}B^{2}_{n}(\lambda)Y_{1}\overset{p}{\to}0.

Above all,

T1‚Äãn‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚ÄãH1‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒî2+(y2‚àíy1)‚ÄãR1‚Äã(Œª),T2‚Äãn‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚ÄãH1‚Äã(Œª)+(y1‚àíy2)‚ÄãR1‚Äã(Œª),subscriptùëá1ùëõùëù‚Üísubscriptùêª1ùúÜsuperscriptŒî2subscriptùë¶2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùëÖ1ùúÜsubscriptùëá2ùëõùëù‚Üísubscriptùêª1ùúÜsubscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶2subscriptùëÖ1ùúÜ\displaystyle T_{1n}\overset{p}{\to}H_{1}(\lambda)\Delta^{2}+(y_{2}-y_{1})R_{1}(\lambda),~{}T_{2n}\overset{p}{\to}H_{1}(\lambda)+(y_{1}-y_{2})R_{1}(\lambda),
T3‚Äãn‚Äã‚Üíùëù‚ÄãH2‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãŒî2+(y1+y2)‚ÄãR2‚Äã(Œª).subscriptùëá3ùëõùëù‚Üísubscriptùêª2ùúÜsuperscriptŒî2subscriptùë¶1subscriptùë¶2subscriptùëÖ2ùúÜ\displaystyle T_{3n}\overset{p}{\to}H_{2}(\lambda)\Delta^{2}+(y_{1}+y_{2})R_{2}(\lambda).

By the continuous mapping theorem, the proof is completed.

7.6 Proof of Proposition 3.1

When

h1‚Äã(t)=‚à´xx+t‚ÄãùëëH‚Äã(x),h2‚Äã(t)=‚à´x(x+t)2‚ÄãùëëH‚Äã(x),formulae-sequencesubscript‚Ñé1ùë°ùë•ùë•ùë°differential-dùêªùë•subscript‚Ñé2ùë°ùë•superscriptùë•ùë°2differential-dùêªùë•\displaystyle h_{1}(t)=\int\frac{x}{x+t}dH(x),~{}h_{2}(t)=\int\frac{x}{(x+t)^{2}}dH(x),

by the definitions of H1‚Äã(Œª)subscriptùêª1ùúÜH_{1}(\lambda) and H2‚Äã(Œª)subscriptùêª2ùúÜH_{2}(\lambda), we have

H1‚Äã(Œª)=subscriptùêª1ùúÜabsent\displaystyle H_{1}(\lambda)= (1+y‚ÄãR1‚Äã(Œª))‚Äãh1‚Äã(Œª‚Äã(1+y‚ÄãR1‚Äã(Œª)))=‚à´1Œªx+11+y‚ÄãR1‚Äã(Œª)‚ÄãùëëH‚Äã(x),1ùë¶subscriptùëÖ1ùúÜsubscript‚Ñé1ùúÜ1ùë¶subscriptùëÖ1ùúÜ1ùúÜùë•11ùë¶subscriptùëÖ1ùúÜdifferential-dùêªùë•\displaystyle(1+yR_{1}(\lambda))h_{1}(\lambda(1+yR_{1}(\lambda)))=\int\frac{1}{\frac{\lambda}{x}+\frac{1}{1+yR_{1}(\lambda)}}dH(x),

and

H2‚Äã(Œª)=subscriptùêª2ùúÜabsent\displaystyle H_{2}(\lambda)= {(1+y‚ÄãR1‚Äã(Œª))2+y‚ÄãR2‚Äã(Œª)}‚Äã‚à´x2(x+Œª‚Äã(1+y‚ÄãR1‚Äã(Œª))2)‚ÄãùëëH‚Äã(x)superscript1ùë¶subscriptùëÖ1ùúÜ2ùë¶subscriptùëÖ2ùúÜsuperscriptùë•2ùë•ùúÜsuperscript1ùë¶subscriptùëÖ1ùúÜ2differential-dùêªùë•\displaystyle\{(1+yR_{1}(\lambda))^{2}+yR_{2}(\lambda)\}\int\frac{x^{2}}{(x+\lambda(1+yR_{1}(\lambda))^{2})}dH(x)
=\displaystyle= ‚à´1+y‚ÄãR2‚Äã(Œª)(1+y‚ÄãR1‚Äã(Œª))2(Œªx+11+y‚ÄãR1‚Äã(Œª))2‚ÄãùëëH‚Äã(x).1ùë¶subscriptùëÖ2ùúÜsuperscript1ùë¶subscriptùëÖ1ùúÜ2superscriptùúÜùë•11ùë¶subscriptùëÖ1ùúÜ2differential-dùêªùë•\displaystyle\int\frac{1+\frac{yR_{2}(\lambda)}{(1+yR_{1}(\lambda))^{2}}}{(\frac{\lambda}{x}+\frac{1}{1+yR_{1}(\lambda)})^{2}}dH(x).

Compared with Lemma 2 of Wang et¬†al. (2015), H1‚Äã(Œª)=R1‚Äã(Œª)subscriptùêª1ùúÜsubscriptùëÖ1ùúÜH_{1}(\lambda)=R_{1}(\lambda) and H2‚Äã(Œª)=R2‚Äã(Œª)subscriptùêª2ùúÜsubscriptùëÖ2ùúÜH_{2}(\lambda)=R_{2}(\lambda). The convergence of misclassification rate is a direct conclusion of Theorem 3.1. The proof is completed.
